prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The intensity of CCH (N=3-2, J=5/2-3/2, F=3-2) line is calculated from that of CCH (N=4-3) lines to be 450 mJy/(0."7 x 0."45 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.14 km/s. Considering that the structure is unresolved or marginally resolved toward the disk in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, the expected intensity with the 0."23 beam is 76 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.6 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with the S/N ratio of 10 or higher.

Since CCH, CS and c-C3H2 trace the kinematic structure of the envelope in L1527, which has a similar chemical composition as IRAS 15398-2422, observations of these molecules will show us the accurate structure of the envelope in this source. We include the 34SO and SO lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. We also include SO2 to learn the strength of the shock around the centrifugal barrier. In our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, the CH3OH lines are weakly detected with very compact distribution around the protostar. It is very important to confirm it with higher resolution observations to explore how significant the hot corino activity is seen in the WCCC source, IRAS 15398-3359. Hence, observations of CH3OH are helpful to characterize the chemical composition of this source. NH2CHO is also interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not.

We would like to delineate the structure of the 35 AU (0".23) scale of CCH, CS and c-C3H2 in order to investigate the kinematic structure of the envelope. Since the structure of the envelope is not resolved enough in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, an observation at a higher spatial resolution is necessary to investigate the structure with the infalling rotating envelope model in detail. This observation and the analysis with the model will provide us with the more accurate physical parameters in this source, and we can confirm its very low mass estimated in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program.

The intensity of H2CO (515-414) line is 450 mJy/(0."6 x 0."44 beam) with velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program. Considering that the structure of the disk is unresolved in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, the expected intensity with the 0."16 beam is 73 mJy/beam or higher. With the rms noise of 7.3 mJy/beam, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with the S/N ratio of 10 or higher.

H2CO lines are included as standard molecular lines to study the disk/envelope structure. By using the K=0, 1, and 2 lines, the gas kinematic temperature and the H2 density are evaluated. In our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, the CH3OH lines are weakly detected with very compact distribution around the protostar. It is very important to confirm it with higher resolution observations to explore how significant the hot corino activity is seen in the WCCC source, IRAS 15398-3359. Hence, observation of CH3OH is helpful to characterize the chemical composition of this source, and we also include CH3CN and DCN for this aim. The c-C3H2 lines are detected in our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program, and if it is detected at high angular resolution, we can derive the temperature and density in the innermost part of the infalling rotating envelope in combination with the lines of c-C3H2 included in the Band 6 setting. We include SO2 to learn the strength of the shock around the centrifugal barrier.

We would like to delineate the structure of the 25 AU (0".16) scale of H2CO in order to confirm the Keplerian disk formed inside of the centrifugal barrier. Since we can derive the protostellar mass with the observation of the Keplerian motion, the very low mass of this source will be determined more accurately by comparing it with the mass derived from the structure of the infalling rotating envelope. The high-velocity components of H2CO detected with our previous ALMA Cycle 0 program are concentrated in the vicinity of the protostar, and they seem to reside only in the radius of 0".1-0".2 from the protostar, which corresponds to 15-30 AU at the distance of 150 pc from the Sun.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In star-formation studies, an important target is to understand when and how the rotationally supported disk is formed around the protostar. In order to address this question, we recently conducted the ALMA observations of the CCH (N=4-3) and H2CO (515-414 etc.) lines in Band 7 toward the low-mass Class 0 protostar IRAS 15398-3359 at a resolution of 0."5. We detected a beautiful outflow feature as well as a flattened envelope around the protostar. From the analysis of the outflow structure, the inclination angle of the envelope is estimated to be 20 degree (i.e. almost edge-on). Then, the velocity structure of the envelope is analyzed, and the mass of the protostar is roughly estimated to be less than 0.09 Msun. Furthermore, the H2CO emission shows a sign of a Keplerian disk. These results will be an important clue to understanding the initial stage of disk formation processes, if confirmed. We here propose to observe the CCH (N=3-2) and H2CO (515-414 etc.) lines in the Band 6 and Band 7 at the resolution of 0."23 and 0."16, respectively. This observation will provide us with a deep insight into the initial stage of disk formation in Class 0 protostars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, University of Tokyo

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
